content: The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". The findings are also included in the Act. During the Lavender Scare, over 1,000 individuals were wrongly fired from the Department of State in the 1950s and 1960s for alleged homosexuality. Department of State employees were forced out due to their sexual orientation being seen as a security risk. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining the Department. Many patriotic Americans were wrongfully dismissed or prevented from joining the Department of State due to their perceived sexual orientation, which was considered a security risk during the Lavender Scare. Congress played a role in these actions as a response to investigations into federal employees' "sex perversion." During the Lavender Scare, the Department of State faced pressure from Congress due to concerns about the presence of homosexuals sympathetic to Communism. Congressional investigations into federal employees' sexual orientation led to actions against perceived security risks. During the Lavender Scare, the Department of State faced pressure from Congress over concerns about homosexuals sympathetic to Communism. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department had to report on fired homosexuals annually to Committees on Appropriations. In the early 1990s, the State Department's security office investigated and removed gay personnel from government service. In the early 1990s, the Department of State's security office investigated and removed gay personnel from government service. In 1994, Secretary of State Warren Christopher prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation, and in 1998, President Clinton signed an Executive Order barring such discrimination. In 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for past discrimination against the LGBTI community and reaffirmed the Department's commitment to diversity and inclusion. SEC. 3. DIRECTOR GENERAL REVIEW. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made publicly available within 270 days of the enactment of this Act, including historical statements from Department of State officials. The Director General will compile information on wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation and create a report with historical statements from officials encouraging such policies. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of Director General's reviews under section 3 and submit reports to Congress. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on employees terminated during the "Lavender Scare". The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of the inappropriate terminations. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on employees terminated during the "Lavender Scare". The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of the inappropriate terminations and offer to change their employment records if desired. A senior-level point of contact will be designated to receive oral testimony from employees or family members who personally experienced the discrimination. The Office of the Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources will receive oral testimony from employees or family members who experienced discrimination or termination due to sexual orientation. Former employees not mentioned in the report can bring forth grievances to the Board if they believe they were terminated for the same reason. The Board will review claims of discrimination or termination based on sexual orientation within 150 days of receiving the claim. The Department of State must provide relevant information to prove that the employee was not wrongfully terminated. Lack of paperwork cannot be used to dismiss any claims. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. The Department of State is responsible for providing information to prove employees were not wrongfully terminated. Lack of paperwork cannot dismiss claims. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry issued an apology on January 9, 2017, expressing support for the LGBTI community and emphasizing the importance of human rights for all individuals. He highlighted the contributions of LGBTI employees at the State Department and efforts to provide equal protections for their families overseas. Kerry also appointed the first Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015 to promote LGBTI rights globally. In 2015, the Department appointed the first Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons to promote LGBTI rights globally and ensure equal protections for their families overseas. The Department acknowledged past discrimination based on sexual orientation and emphasized the importance of respecting human rights for all individuals. The Department apologizes for past discrimination against employees based on perceived sexual orientation and reaffirms commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also offers a formal apology for encouraging discriminatory policies like the "Lavender Scare" at the Department of State. Congress offers a formal apology for its role in the "Lavender Scare" and similar discriminatory policies at the Department of State, which were influenced by congressional investigations into the sexual orientation of federal employees. Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with a public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display oral history materials. The exhibit at the United States Diplomacy Center on the "Lavender Scare" should provide access to reports from the Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, and display oral testimony from employees or family members of deceased employees affected by discriminatory policies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 100 days of this Act, addressing countries denying visas to Foreign Service personnel's spouses based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include ending visa reciprocity with such countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation. SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCEMENT BOARD. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony from affected individuals regarding discrimination based on sexual orientation and will issue reports periodically for five years. The Advancement Board within the Department of State will submit a report to Congress annually for 5 years based on testimony collected regarding discrimination due to sexual orientation, with recommendations for improvement to prevent such discrimination. The Department of State aims to prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation among employees and their families. The report on this issue will be private and accessible only to Members of Congress, their staff, and the Advancement Board.
